Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: The phone in my hand felt heavier than usual as I glanced at the clock—6:30 p.m. My sales numbers were already soaring this week, and my manager’s praise still echoed in my mind. “Keep pushing, don’t let up now. Every call counts.” I could almost taste the bonus. But then my eyes landed on the voter ID card peeking out from my wallet. The polls closed at 8 p.m., and tonight was my only chance to vote. I’d promised myself I’d never miss an election, not after all those years hearing how every vote matters. But the call list was long, and the pressure to keep dialing was relentless. If I left now, I’d lose precious time and maybe a few more sales. If I stayed, I’d miss my chance to have a say in something bigger than quotas. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the expectations of my job and my duty as a citizen, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me.
